title.narrative: Inclusive peace and reconciliation in Sierra Leone (Kolhat Barray)

description.narrative:
1- 360 young women and men (min. 180 female, 120 people at each site), members of youth-led CSOs, CBOs and networks. They will be selected on the basis of their knowledge, skills and existing circles of influence by youth-led CSOs and CBOs pre-screened by Cordaid and YPPD. and empowered through leadership training.
2 - 9 youth-led CSOs, CBOs or networks (min. 1 at each site) will be sub-granted to support research and advocacy activities. They will be selected on the basis of representativeness and local legitimacy with young people in the communities they serve; project implementation track records; and integrity.
3 - 240 members of CBDR providers (min. 60 female), including paramount chiefs, sub-chiefs, chiefdom speakers, local court chairpersons and record-keepers, Customary Law Officers and Local Court Supervisors (lawyers supervising the operations of local courts at provincial and district levels) and District Appeal Courts (to which local court appeals are directed); LPPB members and SLP CROs; DISEC members; LAB personnel; and, in Pujehun, personnel associated with the WFP-led land conflict dialogue mechanisms. Other CBDR providers, such as SDOs, VDC and WDC members, local mammy queens, and CAB personnel, may be invited to participate based on the input of youth-led CSOs and CBOs). CBDR providers will benefit from dialogue, RAPs, and improved public perception and legitimacy.

Nearly two decades on from Sierra Leone’s civil war (1991-2002), there is considerable continuity with pre-war structures and dynamics. The concentration of wealth and power in Freetown, the relative deprivation of rural and peri-urban areas, are fundamental features of the country’s political economy. Mounting public frustration with weak rule of law, corruption, and poor accountability for chronic service delivery failures ensures that Sierra Leone remains fragile and prone to conflict recurrence. As in any context, everyday conflicts are commonplace in Sierra Leone. In societies characterized by cohesion and the rule of law, social norms and institutions provide a framework for fair resolution of conflicts while protecting basic rights, and restrict the use of violence. Due to Sierra Leone’s history of unequal power relations and weak rule of law, everyday conflicts are often resolved in favour of the most powerful party or left unaddressed, resulting in grievances and undermining social cohesion. In rural and peri-urban areas, people struggle to claim rights, address grievances, and resolve conflicts; the ability to do so invariably requires leverage or the intermediation of a powerful patron (sababu), such as a chief. In rural and peri-urban Sierra Leone, the most important everyday conflicts are over land and natural resource rights, matters of family relations and inheritance, debts, petty theft, corruption, witchcraft, farmer-pastoralist disputes, and feuds between neighbours, villages, and schools. The statutory justice system plays only a marginal role in resolving these problems, due to challenges identified in the 2018 UN Common Country Assessment, including long delays, weak institutional capacity (especially in rural areas), lack of judicial independence, and limited support to vulnerable victims. Magistrate’s courts, at the lowest level of the statutory system, are viewed as distant and costly. For these reasons, a 2018 Afrobarometer survey found only one-third (32%) of Sierra Leoneans trusted the statutory courts. Establishment of a Legal Aid Board (LAB) charged with regulating and expanding legal aid service provision has gone some way toward improving access to statutory justice, and LAB Community Advisory Bureaus (CABs) have become important service provision points for the poor. Various forms of community-based dispute resolution (CBDR) are more commonly used by people to claim rights, address grievances, and resolve conflicts outside the magistrate’s courts and in ways that are considered locally legitimate11. Within these institutions, conflict resolution is normally facilitated by respected and influential intermediaries with customary or religious status, advocating settlements that reflect local norms and values. The most widely-used CBDR providers are:
Customary authorities, including paramount chiefs and sub-chiefs with authority over 241 local courts, but also sometimes in irregular chiefdom courts (“chief barrays” or “kangaroo courts”), or acting as more informal mediators, arbitrators, conciliators and counsellors; as well as local court chairpersons, chiefdom speakers, family heads, breadwinners, elders, and secret societies. It is in the local courts, and through the intermediation of chiefs or elders, that 75% of rural Sierra Leoneans resolve problems at local level. While these mechanisms maintain equilibrium and order in communities, they also tend to reinforce gerontocratic and patriarchal power relations, with deleterious effects for youth and young women in particular. Chiefs are represented by the National Council of Paramount Chiefs (NCPC), and policy related to chieftaincy is managed by the Ministry of Local Government and Rural Development (MLGRD).
Local Police Partnership Boards (LPPBs), established in line with the Local Needs Policing ethos of the Sierra Leone Police (SLP), enable communities to participate in solving local safety problems. LPPB members are volunteers operating without much financial support, who intervene on a range of criminal and civil matters and mediate minor disputes within communities and between communities and SLP. LPPBs are supported by SLP Community Relations Officers (CROs), include designated youth and women’s representatives, and have proven to be sustainable in the long-term.
District Security Committees (DISECs) operating under the aegis of the Office of National Security (ONS), a secretariat reporting to the National Security Council (NSC) that advises the President on state security issues, and draws on a broad dispute resolution mandate. DISECs are often activated to respond to land and other disputes between or within communities or families, using mediation, conciliation and arbitration. To a more limited extent, other actors involved in CBDR include those in the formal sector, such as Senior District Officers (SDOs) explicitly vested with dispute resolution authority in the local governance system, and members of sub-district Village and Ward Development Committees (VDCs and WDCs), intended to facilitate grassroots participation in development planning; and the informal sector, like community paralegals, faith leaders, mammy queens, okada (motorcycle) rider unions, and market traders’ associations. Notably, these CBDR structures are recognized at community level but not always well-linked to one another, and no national agency is tasked with overall oversight or monitoring. In Pujehun, a WFP-led, PBF-funded initiative is currently building a new infrastructure for inclusive dialogue around land conflict (in Makpele and Malen chiefdoms).
Due to conservative and gerontocratic social norms and systematic forms of exclusion, young people, and especially young women, are least likely to possess the leverage or patronage to claim rights, address grievances, and resolve disputes through CBDR mechanisms. While young people make up 80% of Sierra Leone’s population, their autonomy, agency, and political and economic power is severely limited; collectively, they experience the structural and psychological exclusion rooted in reciprocal mistrust of duty-bearers and power-holders (as identified, for example, in The Missing Peace: Independent Progress Study on Youth, Peace and Security). Especially in rural and peri-urban areas, young women and men lack the sababu needed, for example, to find redress for abuse in a paramount chief’s court, or mobilize the SLP for protection when they experience violence. This leaves youth more vulnerable to insecurity and injustice, and it ensures that young people are seldom active participants in community-level conflict resolution, with often conflict generative implications. Indeed, Sierra Leone’s Truth and Reconciliation Commission (TRC) noted that marginalization of youth, especially rural youth, and arbitrary and capricious application of customary law by the chieftaincy, were among factors that gave rise to the civil war.
The intersection of generational and gendered exclusions means that young women are doubly disadvantaged. For example: about half of all Sierra Leonean women are victims of sexual and gender-based violence (SGBV) in their lifetimes. Customary law reifies discriminatory attitudes and behaviours that deny women justice for SGBV; incidents of sexual violence are often regarded as local “disputes,” to be settled between families in private with money changing hands, thereby disincentivizing women to report SGBV, and leaves offenders with impunity. Victim-shaming is a particular risk for young women, who may be blamed by community members (including older women) for bringing sexual violence or harassment onto themselves because of occupation, lifestyle or dress; young women may be deterred from seeking justice in community-based fora that afford no privacy, or place them at risk of vendetta-driven witchcraft accusations. Whereas customary institutions like women’s secret societies may be able to support older women seeking justice or dispute resolution, younger women have fewer options for leverage.
The lack of youth participation in local-level CBDR is mirrored by the general weakness and non-inclusive implementation of conflict prevention policy at national level. Despite political commitments and donor investments (including, notably, UN PBF-funded initiatives), there is no dedicated, nationally-owned conflict prevention and resolution architecture. ONS plays a central role in a national early warning and response capability under the NSC, but multi-stakeholder cooperation around conflict prevention related to electoral cycles has not translated into a coherent policy or infrastructure for peace. This is especially concerning given that Sierra Leone will enter another contentious electoral cycle over the next three years.
The systematic exclusion of young women and men from CBDR disables their active citizenship and potential contributions to a more stable social contract. The risk that unresolved conflicts could be destabilizing has grown. A 2020 Afrobarometer survey16 found only half of Sierra Leoneans satisfied with government performance preventing or resolving violent community conflict, and only 20% meeting needs of youth. The absence of inclusive mechanisms that deal with power and resource-sharing among Sierra Leone’s people at community level will aggravate local conflict, and a return to instability remains a significant risk.

To create an enabling environment for young women and men, working intergenerationally, to encourage active citizenship and collectively influence conflict prevention practices at local and national levels, contributing to a more inclusive and peaceful society for all Sierra Leoneans.

participating-org.narrative: Youth Partnership for Peace and Development

mailing-address.narrative: Grote Marktstraat 45, Den Haag, Zuid Holland, 2511 BH

title.narrative: Peace Corporate Indictors
Number of beneficiaries reached (PE)

description.narrative: Number of people who benefitted directly/indirectly through activities implemented or services established/enabled/improved by a Cordaid peace, security and justice project/programme

title.narrative: Number of people that meaningfully engage in peace processes at various levels

description.narrative: Count (or estimate if precise count not possible) number of project beneficiaries (constituencies) directly engaged in peace processes supported by the project. Their meaningful engagement needs to be analysed and supported by evidence like documented positive outcomes, satisfaction surveys results or other proof of having a voice in the peace process. Include in comments whether count or estimation, if estimation include a description of how that estimate was calculated).

title.narrative: Number of security and justice institutions (formal and informal) strengthened to provide better security and justice services

description.narrative: Count institutions supported by the project in improving their functioning resulting in better service provision towards vulnerable groups. Justice institutions can be part of the formal justice system or implement informal, customary law. Security institution include police, armed forces or peacekeeping missions. Institutions can operate at national level like Departments of Ministries or at local level like police stations and local courts. Specify in the comments which institutions have strengthened their capacities. Institutions are considered "strengthened" if they have become more responsive, accountable and inclusive.

title.narrative: Number of CSOs that meaningfully engage in peace processes at various levels

description.narrative: Count number of CSOs (local, national and international) involved in peace processes supported by the project. Their meaningful engagement needs to be analysed and supported by evidence like documented positive outcomes, surveys results or other proof of CSO influence on the peace process.

title.narrative: Number of People effectively participating in decision-making processes on security, and justice at local level

description.narrative: Count number of project beneficiaries (constituencies) engaged in local decision making processes on security and justice supported by the project. Their effective participation needs to be analysed and supported by evidence like documented positive outcomes, satisfaction surveys results or other proof of influencing outcomes.

title.narrative: Number of civil society actors with strengthened organizational and advocacy capacity to work on issues of security, justice and peace

description.narrative: Count number of strengthened CSOs, CBOs and civil society movements involved lobby and advocacy supported by the project. Strengthened capacity needs to be analysed and supported by evidence like documented capacity assessments, positive L&A outcomes, improved strategic choices, and results of L&A training. Note that The number of civil society actors that increased capacity for L&A can be higher than the number of our partners.

title.narrative: Number of laws and policies by institutions on security, justice and peace influenced by civil society

description.narrative: The indicator aims to measure the influence of civil society in policy making. Count the number of approved laws or supporting policies that contribute to better service provision towards vulnerable groups. A plausible influence needs to be supported by documented outcomes of advocacy. Counted changes can vary from national laws to locally adopted policies. Explain in the comments what policies were changed and how they benefit the project's constituencies.

title.narrative: Number of inclusive peace building processes at national and local level involving CSOs, women and youth

description.narrative: The indicator aims to measure the number of processes in which the project has successfully supported civil society in claiming an influential role in the process and outcomes of the negotiation process.

title.narrative: Number of people satisfied with the quality of justice & security services and peace processes

description.narrative: The satisfaction of beneficiaries (constituencies) is an important indication for improved services or inclusiveness of peace processes. Based on satisfaction surveys carried out with a careful sample of the project’s beneficiaries (specified at least by gender and age) changes in satisfaction can be monitored (Only report on where relevant) (only if obligatory)

title.narrative: Project aims to strengthen the capacities of civil society organizations and people to promote social cohesion at the local level (Yes/No)

description.narrative: Yes if the project supports social cohesion based on the assumption that promoting social cohesion depends on the local capacity of civil society. Capacity strengthening can include training workshops, exchanges, networking, stakeholder dialogue and participatory analysis etc.

title.narrative: Number of people with improved access to more responsive, accountable and inclusive security and justice services

description.narrative: "The indicators measures the impact resulting from project interventions. Only count the number of people who gained access to services because of improved functioning of security of justice institutions in the project area during the reporting period. The improved service can result from a better (implementation of) legislative framework and/or strengthened capacities of the institutions. Since the number is likely to be based on calculation, a precise justification of how this was done needs to be provided (in comment section). This indicator can be linked to indicators for: 1) improved legislation. However, improved legislation can NOT be assumed to benefit the entire population of the project area, and any claimed number of people m by calculating the people directly benefitting from their improved services of these institutions. Justice institutions can be part of the formal justice system or implement informal, customary law. Security institution include police, armed forces or peacekeeping missions."

title.narrative: Peace Project Specific Indicators
% youth satisfaction with responsiveness and accountability of CBDR providers
% of young women and men with Improve perception of the space for their engagement and willingness of decision makers to respond to their demands

% of young women and men with Improved knowledge, attitudes and skills related to personal and organizational leadership, organizing, conflict analysis and mitigation, advocacy, and engaging young men as allies in defending women's right
Self-assessment score of CBDR providers in inclusiveness
% young leaders who perceive an increase of participation and influence in conflict prevention policy processes
% inclusion of youth in key policy processes
# of Young women and men actively monitor change in CBDR activities and outcomes and provide regular feedback to CBDR providers on inclusivity, gender-sensitivity and conflict- sensitivity
# of youth trained
# of Web-based dialogues and networking
# of briefings conducted with key international stakeholders such as UN Country Team and key diplomatic missions (esp. major donor partners)
# of Policy impact tracked and documented by partners
# of national knowledge-sharing event amongst youth and between youth and key stakeholders on conflict prevention, security and justice facilitated

# of briefings with duty-bearers and powerholders at national level, including ONS, SLP, NCPC, LAB, Office of the President and Chief Minister, relevant line ministries (MLGRD, MoGCA, etc.), relevant parliamentary committees, HRCSL, Office of the Ombudsman, electoral institutions, National Youth Commission, and political party representatives
# of sub-granted projects aimed to improve inclusiveness, gender-sensitivity and conflict-sensitivity of CBDR implemented
# of community dialogues between youth and CBDR providers implemented
% youth with improved perception of CBDR provider performance in four areas
Empowerment
Number of people who have participated in formal and informal decision-making directly influencing aspects of their lives

description.narrative: Number of people indicating they participated in formal and informal decision-making directly influencing aspects of their lives, comparing from before Cordaid/partner interventions to after (baseline to endline).

title.narrative: Number of laws and policies implemented for sustainable and inclusive development

description.narrative: Number of inclusive policies implemented by governments and other influential stakeholders; to be measured by comparing Contextual Analysis from before Cordaid/partner interventions to after (baseline to endline). Inclusivity refers to otherwise excluded groups of society like women, youth, ethnic groups, PLWD etc. Include an explanation of your result in the comments section of DevResults

title.narrative: Number of (formal & informal) structural spaces maintained, created and/or strengthened

description.narrative: Number of structural spaces - both formal and informal - for participatory and inclusive democratic dialogue between local stakeholders maintained, created and/or strengthened; to be measured by comparing Contextual Analysis from before Cordaid/partner interventions to after (baseline to endline)

title.narrative: Number of civil society partners strengthened to represent the interests of their constituencies

description.narrative: Number of civil society partners able due to relevant Cordaid project activities to represent the interests of their consituencies vis a vis other stakeholders ( like government at all levels, private sector). The civil society parners are to be disagregated by women's rights CSOs; youth lead CSOs and other CSOs.

title.narrative: Number of collective actions where people demand their rights for (quality) basic services

description.narrative: Number of collective actions where people demand their rights for (increased quality) basic services (including health, education, security, justice etc.) as a result of/with contribution from Cordaid programme activities.

title.narrative: Number of local partner organizations that are engaged in equitable partnerships with Cordaid

description.narrative: Number of partnerships scoring a total of 3 and above when using the Power Awareness Tool, which Cordaid uses for partnerships with local partner organisations (with budget above 500'000Euro) at the start, in monitoring and end of the projects.

title.narrative: Accountability
% of feedback and valid complaints received that are responded to/resolved

description.narrative: Percent of feedback and valid complaints received at project or country/field office level, via Cordaid, a partner or consortium member that are respond to and/or resolved (in accordance with Cordaid FCM minimum standards). This excludes invalid and sensitive complaints.

title.narrative: Climate Resilience
The project integrates climate risks in programming

description.narrative: The integration of climate risks in programming includes an undertaking of concrete actions to reduce and/or mitigate risks related to climate change impact and disaster risks ( for example droughts, erosion, salinization, flooding, etc.) The projects we refer to could be on the themes of health education, justice, security, disaster management, finance and livelihoods.

title.narrative: Peace Thematic Indicators
Number of communities reached (SJ)
